pages.text: First named by Harry Seeley in 1874, Rhomaleosaurus (meaning "strong lizard") was a rhomaleosaurid pliosauroid plesiosaur that swam the Early Jurassic seas (roughly 183 - 175.6 million years ago) of what is now Northamptonshire and Yorkshire in the UK. This 6.7 - 7 metre (22 - 23 feet) long animal was a major predator, likely feeding on a range of smaller marine animals.

Like other taxa in its clade, Rhomaleosaurus may have been able to force water through passages in its skull containing smell receptors, allowing it to track prey in a manner similar to many modern sharks. Its name means strong lizard. It was one of the earliest large marine reptiles of the Mesozoic era. The long neck was presumably used in hunting, in order to catch animals further away from it.
